info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 4, game 2.

(1, 1).clue: John Queeny founded the chemical company Monsanto in St. Louis in 1901 to make this sweetener

(2, 1).clue: "You've stuck your webs into my business for the last time!"

(3, 1).clue: The famous American Indian Geronimo spent his childhood in this "dogged" Mexican region

(4, 1).clue: AKA a dun, this 4-winged insect has multiple tails & does not eat

(5, 1).clue: I always update the antivirus definitions for this Symantec Corp. program; it's not named for Kramden's pal

(6, 1).clue: Popular term for a person born in the U.S. between 1946 & 1965

(1, 2).clue: A dipole is a molecule in which this is opposite at the 2 poles

(2, 2).clue: "One thing about trains, it doesn't matter where they're going.  What matters is deciding to get on"

(3, 2).clue: In English, this nation's national anthem begins, "Arise children of the fatherland, the day of glory has arrived"

(4, 2).clue: She collaborated with Warren Beatty on "Heaven Can Wait" (hooray!) & on "Ishtar" (did we mention "Heaven Can Wait"?)

(5, 2).clue: I've been using this product created in 1984 by the Intuit owner after he saw his wife tediously pay the bills

(6, 2).clue: One of these is given by your doctor to maintain or renew your immunity to a disease

(1, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from beside a mummy from Cairo, Egypt.)  To remove all the moisture from a body, natron, a variety of this, was applied both inside & outside the corpse

(3, 3).clue: Between 1961 & 1983, this nation sent numerous Venera probes to Venus to study its atmosphere & chemical makeup

(4, 3).clue: Swedes set these up for their midsummer festivals in June--a few weeks late, we think

(5, 3).clue: I'm now using the Firefox web browser that got its start from this Time Warner company's Netscape division

(6, 3).clue: In this hobby that's all the rage, you create fun and memorable pages like the ones seen here

(1, 4).clue: In 1947 Willard Libby perfected the archaeological dating method named for this isotope

(2, 4).clue: "I'm going to steal the Declaration of Independence!"

(3, 4).clue: Nawaz Sharif was the prime minister of this nation until deposed by its current military leader

(4, 4).clue: Cape May is a resort town in this state, down the shore from Point Pleasant

(5, 4).clue: Like the asbestos partitions on my house, I use ZoneAlarm as this type of software to keep my computer secure

(6, 4).clue: A popular balloon-busting game of the 1960s, or a General Mills cereal from the same era

(1, 5).clue: Adjective for a substance that evaporates readily; pronounced differently, it follows "sal"

(2, 5).clue: "Is there no one else? Is there no one else?"

(3, 5).clue: 2 cities, both named Tripoli, are Libya's largest & this country's second-largest

(4, 5).clue: Her first novel, "Moods", was published in 1864

(5, 5).clue: I don't click on an email link to update any of my accounts, because it may be this type of "sporting" spam

(6, 5).clue: Another word for pirate, it's derived from the same Dutch word as "filibuster"

(2, 1).clue: Inducting this group, Springsteen said, "Uno, dos, tres, catorce" (1, 2, 3, 14) "is the correct math for rock 'n' roll"

(4, 1).clue: Rudolph is the commander of Gessler's archers in this opera

(5, 1).clue: A reading room at the Lorain Public Library in Ohio is named for this "Beloved" prize-winner from 1988

(6, 1).clue: 6-letter word used to express sorrow or regret

(2, 2).clue: At the induction ceremony, Percy Sledge sang this classic hit of his & dedicated it to his wife Rosa

(3, 2).clue: He was the majority stockholder in MGM until it was sold to Sony in 2005

(4, 2).clue: He's the local barber & general busybody in an 1816 Rossini opera

(5, 2).clue: In 1923 she won a Pulitzer for her novel "One of Ours", set where else but in Nebraska

(6, 2).clue: It was previously known as cante & baile gitano, "Gypsy" song & dance

(2, 3).clue: "Put Your Hands Together" for this "Love Train" group that joined the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 2005

(3, 3).clue: Before writing his first novel, he worked as a night attendant in the mental ward of a V.A. hospital

(4, 3).clue: The prince sings, "Si, ritrovarla, io guiro" ("Yes, I will find her, I swear it") in this fairy tale opera

(5, 3).clue: Her Cross Creek farmhouse where she penned "The Yearling" is part of a state historic site in Florida

(6, 3).clue: It flows into the Columbia River at Portland

(2, 4).clue: Drummer Martin Chambers was inducted as part of this "Middle Of The Road" group

(3, 4).clue: Poem that mentions "A sunny pleasure dome with caves of ice"

(4, 4).clue: This 1819 Rossini opera is based on a poem by Sir Walter Scott

(5, 4).clue: This member of a prominent Boston family won a 1926 Pulitzer for her poetry collection "What's O'Clock"

(6, 4).clue: In botany, it's the stalklike portion of a stamen, supporting the anther

(2, 5).clue: The Hall honored Seymour Stein, the co-founder of this record label, who's credited with discovering & signing Madonna

(3, 5).clue: On radio, this bandleader had a "Kollege of Musical Knowledge"

(4, 5).clue: The title character of this 1816 opera is in service with the Venetian army

(5, 5).clue: Sadly, like her friend & fellow poet Sylvia Plath, this winner for "Live or Die" died by her own hand, in 1974

(6, 5).clue: A thin membrane or layer, as of bone, tissue or cell walls

(0, 0).clue: Some of the periods of time called this occurred in 304 A.D. (4 years), 1314 (2 years), 1958 (19 days), 1963 & 2005
